entry.title: Xi Jinping is the ‘most powerful man’ in the world
entry.summary:
Curtin University political analyst Professor Joe Siracusa says he considers China’s President Xi Jinping to be the most “powerful man in the world”.
“In terms of, if you define powerful in getting everyone to do exactly what you want to do as soon as possible, I’d say he is the most powerful man in the world,” Prof Siracusa told Sky News Australia.
“The Chinese are inclined to believe him right now because, let’s face it, he is the only show in town.”

author.name: Latest World News Headlines | Daily Telegraph

entry.title: ‘No surprises’ from Xi Jinping’s speech
entry.summary:
Former Liberal MP Dave Sharma says there were no particular “surprises” in China's President Xi Jinping’s speech with “no suggestions” his plan to remain the country’s leader will change.
“His language about external threats, stormy seas, approach to Taiwan, is not that different to the quite hawkish tone that he’s struck over the past half-decade,” he told Sky News Australia.

entry.title: UK govt plans to limit protest action
entry.summary:
Rights groups have denounced the UK government's plans to make more types of protests illegal.
The laws would give police more powers to break up demonstrations and arrest protesters.
Critics say the proposals are anti-free speech and worse than laws enforced in totalitarian regimes.

author.name: Latest World News Headlines | Daily Telegraph

entry.title: Xi’s ‘soon-to-be’ re-election the ‘biggest political event’ of the year
entry.summary:
The soon-to-be election of China’s President Xi Jinping as the third-time leader of the Communist Party is the “biggest political event” of the year, Curtin University political analyst Professor Joe Siracusa says.
“He is 69 years old, he can count another five years and maybe five years after that,” Prof Siracusa told Sky News Australia.
“He has thrown in prison everybody who has got in his way – he is a pretty ruthless guy.”

author.name: Latest World News Headlines | Daily Telegraph

entry.title: Russia-Ukraine war outcome will determine ‘shape of the world’
entry.summary:
Former Liberal MP Dave Sharma says the outcome of the war between Russia and Ukraine will determine the “shape of the world” for the next few decades.
“If Russia is seen to be able to take territory by force and keep it successfully, then that will carte blanche to any number of countries, not least of which China in our own region,” he told Sky News Australia.
“So it’s incredibly important this progression is repelled.”

author.name: Latest World News Headlines | Daily Telegraph

entry.title: US computer chip export rules having ‘dramatic effect’ on Chinese manufacturing
entry.summary:
Former DFAT Australia-China Council scholar Andrew Phelan says the US sanctions recently imposed on the export of high-end computer chips to China have had a “dramatic” and immediate effect on manufacturing in the country.
The Biden administration recently announced a set of controls that restrict the export of advanced chips, chipmaking equipment and design software created with technology from the United States.
“Every American engineering executive involved in the chip manufacturing, chip industry in China has resigned, effectively immediately,” Mr Phelan told Sky News Australia.
“And ASML, the Dutch supplier of the capital equipment that is used in making high-end chips has ceased servicing its Chinese customers.
“So … I think the Americans anticipated the third term, they were worried about China’s advances in chips, in artificial intelligence, in weaponizing these things, so they have stepped in, in what is the biggest I think US move against China in the last several years.”

entry.title: Despite sanctions, Russian fuel is still selling — here’s who’s buying
entry.summary:
The Russia-flagged vessel Volga River Taganrog oil tanker passes south through the Bosphorus Straits. | Diego Cupolo/NurPhoto via Getty Images
New markets and illicit tactics are part of Russia’s strategy for making up losses. While Russia deals with increasing losses on the battlefield, gradually increasing sanctions have created their own pressure since the invasion of Ukraine began on February 24 of this year. Led by the United States and European Union, sanctions on Russia’s massive energy sector have forced the Russian economy to replace losses from the European market with both legal and illicit energy sales. In the US, President Joe Biden issued an executive order prohibiting the import of Russian petroleum products, liquid natural gas (LNG), and coal products as of March…

entry.title: India Aims to Develop Crypto SOPs During G20 Presidency, Says Finance Minister
entry.summary:
India’s Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has revealed India’s plans to develop Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for cryptocurrencies during its G20 Presidency, from December 1, 2022 to November 30, 2023. Sitharaman has already called for global collaboration to decide the future of crypto and has been cautious against mainstream crypto adoption citing financial stability risks. However, speaking to local Indian journalists on October 15, she confirmed, “This (crypto) will also be part of India’s business (agenda during the G20 presidency). The G20, or Group of Twenty, is a global forum for addressing major issues related to the global economy. According to Sitharaman, no country alone can effectively manage or regulate crypto, adding that:
“But if it’s platforms, asset exchanges that have been created, buying and selling making profits and most importantly, these countries are able to understand the trade of money, are we able to establish for what purpose it is used?
Sitharaman further pointed to the use of crypto assets in money laundering, detected by India’s law enforcement agency, the Enforcement Directorate. She added that G20 members have also acknowledged the same concerns while reiterating the need for all countries to participate when it comes to effectively regulating crypto assets. Related: Polygon Powers Indian Police Complaints Portal and Fights Corruption On October 7, the Reserve Bank of India released a list of proposed features and the reasoning behind its development. central bank digital currency (CBDC). The 51-page document summarizes the main motivations for issuing the digital rupee, including trust, security, liquidity, finality and settlement integrity. Some of the main motivations behind Indian digital currency are reducing operational costs and improving financial inclusion.
Source Link

entry.title: Pope urges UN reform after Ukraine war, COVID 'limits'
entry.summary: Pope Francis said the need to reform the United Nations was "more than obvious" after the Covid-19 pandemic and the Ukraine war exposed its limits, in an extract of his new book published Sunday. The Argentine pontiff said Russia's February invasion of Ukraine highlighted the need to ensure the current multilateral structure -- especially the UN Security Council -- finds "more agile and effective ways of resolving conflicts". "In wartime, it is essential to affirm that we need more multilateralism and a better multilateralism," but the UN is no longer fit for "new realities", he added in an extract published by La Stampa daily. The organization was founded to prevent the horrors of two World Wars from happening again, but although the threat represented by those conflicts was still alive, "today's world is no longer the same", said Francis. "The necessity of these reforms became more than obvious after the pandemic" when the current multilateral system "showed all its limits", he added. Francis denounced the unequal distribution of vaccines as a "glaring example" of the law of the strongest prevailing over solidarity. The 85-year-old advocated "organic reforms" aimed at allowing international organizations to rediscover their essential purpose of "serving the human family" and said international institutions must be the result of the "widest possible consensus". The pope also proposed guaranteeing food, health, economic and social rights on which international institutions would base their decisions. Francis's new book, "I ask you in the name of God: Ten prayers for a future of hope", is due to come out in Italy Tuesday. © 2022 AFP

entry.title: Major flooding in Crete kills two
entry.summary: Two people were killed after torrential rain brought major flooding to the Greek island of Crete, firefighters said on Sunday. Rain started to fall on Saturday morning in the southern Greek island, a popular holiday destination, hitting the Heraklion region particularly hard. Greek firefighters said the body of a 49-year-old woman was found in the sea on Sunday, raising the death toll to two from the floods. On Saturday, a man in his 50s was found dead after he was trapped in his car as torrential rains began. The two individuals were going to Heraklion for work, Greek public television ERT reported. A second missing individual was found alive on Saturday evening. The rains forced the evacuation of several homes and unleashed extensive damage in seaside villages, where streets became rivers carrying away everything in their path, local media reported. The flash floods pushed several cars into the sea along the beach of the seaside resort of Agia Pelagia, with some almost completely submerged in the water surrounded by debris. The beach was covered in scrap including plastic bottles and toys, next to straw umbrellas. The flooding also damaged more than 15 shops, mainly fine restaurants, in Agia Pelagia, popular with wealthy diners. The Civil Defence department said it was mobilised and asked all citizens to be vigilant on Sunday in Crete and the surrounding islands of Rhodes, Karpathos, Kastellorizo and Kasos. © 2022 AFP

Should everything go to plan for Xi, the 69-year-old will be reconfirmed as the party's general secretary after the week-long meeting, cementing his position as China's most powerful leader since Mao Zedong. A heavy police presence was in place around Beijing early Sunday as authorities prepared for the twice-a-decade Congress -- set to open at 10 am (0200 GMT) at the Great Hall of the People in Tiananmen Square. entry.title: Mexico: the promised land for migrants... from the US
entry.summary: While many migrants risk their lives chasing the American dream, Gabriel Zarate fled the rising cost of living in California and moved to the Mexican border city of Tijuana. The 38-year-old Chilean American now crosses over to work in San Diego as an English teacher during the day and returns home in the evening to Mexico. "One of the biggest reasons is the cost of living in Tijuana. It's significantly cheaper than in California," Zarate said. Also, he added: "I love Mexican people and food." His neighbor and fellow English teacher Mike Rachfal also made the move from San Diego, where he used to pay $1,275 a month to rent a studio. "Here it's about half that," the 36-year-old said. The cheaper rents can be a sensitive subject in Mexico, where wages are much lower than in the United States …

entry.title: Treasurer Chalmers to return from United States
entry.summary:
Treasurer Jim Chalmers is returning from the United States from an “eventful pre-budget trip,” Sky News Political Editor Andrew Clennell says.
“He was in one of the last meetings Kwasi Kwarteng had as UK Chancellor of the Exchequer before Kwarteng was sacked by Prime Minister Liz Truss in Britain,” Mr Clennell said.
“Kwarteng appeared agitated and distracted during the meetings apparently - and some of the speeches at the G20 finance ministers forum must have been uncomfortable for him - given they all stressed having your budget in line with central bank policy, and the UK Chancellor, then UK Chancellor, had gone for some big unscheduled tax cuts.
“Our Treasurer met with the Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell just hours after a surprise high annual inflation figure of 8.2 per cent was recorded in the US.”

entry.title: Fire and gunshots at Tehran jail holding Iranian political prisoners — including U.S. citizens
entry.summary:
State news agency IRNA said eight people were injured in the unrest, which erupted after nearly a month of protests across Iran over the death in detention of Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old Kurdish Iranian woman.
The protests have posed one of the most serious challenges to the Islamic Republic since the 1979 revolution, with demonstrations spreading across the country and some people chanting for the death of Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
An Iranian judiciary statement said a prison workshop was set on fire "after a fight among a number of prisoners convicted of financial crimes and theft". Tehran's fire department told state media the cause of the incident was under investigation.
The prison, located in the foothills at the northern edge of the Iranian capital, holds …

entry.title: America first megadonor Peter Thiel seeks citizenship from Mediterranean island: report
entry.summary: One of the largest individual donors in the 2022 midterm elections is seeking to obtain citizenship in Malta, The New York Times reported on Saturday. The newspaper based its report on documents it had viewed and "three people with knowledge of the matter." "Mr. Thiel, 55, is in the process of acquiring at least his third passport even as he expands his financial influence over American politics," the newspaper reported. "Since backing Donald J. Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, the technology investor has become one of the largest individual donors in the midterm elections next month, spending more than $30 million on more than a dozen right-wing Congressional candidates who have decried globalization and pledged to put America first." Thiel also has a New Zealand passport. "There is no obvious tax benefit to Mr. Thiel to gaining Maltese citizenship, lawyers and immigration experts said, though wealthy Saudi, Russian and Chinese citizens sometimes seek a passport from the island nation for European Union access and to hedge against social or political turmoil at home," The Times reported. "What is clear is that a Maltese passport would give Mr. Thiel an escape hatch from the United States if his spending doesn’t change the country to his liking." Thiel has been a major backer of the U.S. Senate campaigns of Blake Masters in Arizona and J.D. Vance in Ohio. "Both candidates have espoused a form of nationalism that, in part, blames globalization and leaders’ involvement in international affairs for American stagnation," the newspaper reported. "Mr. Thiel has endorsed that worldview with his money and in speeches, including one at the National Conservatism Conference last year where he called nationalism 'a corrective' to the 'brain-dead, one-world state' of globalism." Read the full report.

entry.title: Elon Musk backtracks — SpaceX will keep funding Starlink in Ukraine: 'The hell with it'
entry.summary:
Starlink, a constellation of more than 3,000 small satellites in low Earth orbit, has been vital to Ukraine's communications as it battles Russia.
But Musk has found himself embroiled of late in public spats with Ukrainian leaders who were angered by his controversial proposals for de-escalating the conflict, which included acknowledging Russian sovereignty over Crimea.
"The hell with it," Musk, the world's richest man, wrote on Twitter.
"Even though Starlink is still losing money & other companies are getting billions of taxpayer $, we'll just keep funding Ukraine govt for free."
In a series of tweets Friday, Musk had detailed the logistics of the operation and said it was costing SpaceX nearly $20 million per month, and suggested the company could not fund it indefini…

entry.title: Biden's student loan forgiveness plan is a great idea. Let's hope this actually happens.
entry.summary:
It took us far too long to come to this, so I implore the Biden administration to do everything in their power to prevent the student debt forgiveness movement from entering its flop era already.
In August, to my good surprise, President Joe Biden announcement forgiveness of up to $20,000 in student loan debt for certain borrowers ― fulfilling a campaign promise that people like me noticed did not look like a priority of his administration.
“People can finally start to get out of this mountain of debt to pay rent and utilities, to finally think about buying a house, starting a family or starting a business,” Biden said at the White House in remarks detailing the plan. “And by the way, when that happens, the whole economy gets better.”
That amount is arguably still pretty cheap…

entry.title: Daylight Savings Time: Could moving our clocks forward and backward soon be a thing of the past?
entry.summary:
For high school teacher and mother Jennifer Shaffer, time and sleep are two precious assets. So with the end of DST approaching, the busy mother says she fears changing the clock. “It’s definitely going to mess us up and mess us up over the next few days, even a week,” Shaffer told CBS News. She is not alone. according to one vote conducted by Monmouth University, six out of 10 Americans said they would rather make daylight saving time permanent — abandoning the practice of changing the clock twice a year created during World War I to save energy.
Turning our clocks back and forth may soon be a thing of the past – if a few lawmakers get their way. This year, Congress brought the issue into the spotlight when the House energy committee heard testimony at a formal hearing about how changing the clock is linked to increased risk of depression, stroke and sleep disorders. According to National Children’s Hospital sleep specialist Dr. Tyish Hall Brown, changing watches can have an impact on the body. “We have a kind of internal rhythm to our bodies and our health,” Brown said. “And every time we move forward or backward, that too has to adjust.” In March, the US Senate unanimously legislation passed without warning to make DST permanent starting in 2023, if the US House and President agree. Michigan Congressman Fred Upton said the effort will likely fall short in the House, in part because some people in the western section of the time zones say they are concerned that permanent daylight saving time could make mornings too dark and late. “Not only would [school buses] running in the dark, the kids would probably be in the second or third hour while it was still dark,” he said. Nearly 15 years ago, Upton championed an energy-saving law that extended DST even later in November. “Particularly with global warming, climate change is real,” he said. “Why not take advantage of this extra hour of sunlight?”
Source Link

entry.title: Eric Trump's new massive screw-up could cost Republicans in the midterms
entry.summary:
At a time when Republicans across the country are trying to downplay or flee Trump, Eric Trump went on TV to announce that the Republican Party is now Trump’s party. video:
Eric Trump on Newsmax: When we’re on that stage, we know you’re going to find out who your true friends are. My father was the first thing he said to our family, you know? I love fighting for this country. We use a surprising number of arrows, but we love red, white and blue. Well, I sure hope my dad does it again. I think he is the best president this country has ever had. He is willing to fight. No other Republican is willing to fight and I think he fundamentally changed the party. Republicans are no longer Republicans. This is the Trump Party. Republicans are in a tight House race across the country. Swing district candidates are trying to pretend Donald Trump doesn’t exist, and here’s Eric Trump reminding America that voting for any Republican on the 2022 ballot is as good as voting for Donald Trump. Republicans likely won’t win control of the Senate, as Trump’s Senate roster is a massive failure. The GOP needs Donald Trump to leave on Election Day. His presence in the midterms hurt Republican voters. Instead, Eric Trump is touching his father’s ego and reminding every voter in America that the Republican Party that was once the party of Lincoln, Eisenhower and Reagan now belongs to Donald Trump.
Source: Politicususa.com

entry.title: Waste of money: Increasing federal aid to schools during COVID won't help learning loss
entry.summary: U.S. students are struggling even as the government provides school districts with billions of dollars in COVID-19 relief to offset learning losses, according to a study released Tuesday. The study said federal generosity was insufficient, failed to target schools most in need, and was not associated with policy outcomes. Analysts at the American Educational Research Association said schools may need $700 billion to address learning losses, mainly from remote instruction, but received about $189 billion in emergency relief funds for elementary and secondary schools in 2020 and 2021. The funds, including the roughly $120 billion invested last year in President Biden’s massive pandemic relief bill, are aimed at measures such as increasing tutoring, offering extracurricular activities and buy…

entry.title: Legal experts: Trump is employing Hitler's 'Munich model' as he continues his war with the DOJ
entry.summary: Echos of Adolph Hitler's pre-World War II tactics are at the heart of Donald Trump's classified documents scandal, according to a new analysis by two top legal experts. Harvard Law's Laurence Tribe, who has argued three-dozen cases before the U.S. Supreme Court, penned the analysis with Dennis Aftergut, a fellow high court litigator. "In the annals of successful political extortions, few rival the one that took place in Munich more than 80 years ago," Tribe and Aftergut wrote for The Bulwark. "On September 29, 1938, two days before a deadline that Hitler had announced for invading Czechoslovakia, British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain yielded and agreed to meet with the German chancellor. In the Bavarian capital, they signed a 'nonaggression' pact that ceded the territory to Hitler wit…

entry.title: Oil depot hit and on fire in Russia's Belgorodd: governor
entry.summary: An oil depot in Russia's Belgorod region bordering Ukraine is on fire after being shelled on Saturday, the governor said, as strikes increase against the area. "We're getting bombed again. One of the shells hit the oil depot in the Belgorod region," regional governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said. He said emergency services were already on site, adding there was "no risk" of the fire spreading. Gladkov posted a photo showing flames and plumes of black smoke rising above a building. State-run news agency TASS cited a source in the emergency services saying the burning depot was located in the village of Razumnoye-71, near the city of Belgorod. Last week Russia complained of an increase in artillery and missile strikes on its territory bordering Ukraine. The Belgorod region has regularly come under fire. The capital of the region, also called Belgorod, had been hit more rarely. But on Friday a power station in the city was set on fire by a Ukrainian strike, causing electricity cuts. This came a day after a rocket gutted the top floor of an apartment building in the city of Belgorod, without causing injuries. A munition depot in the region was also destroyed on Thursday. Earlier in the week, Ukrainian strikes knocked out power in the town of Shebekino, in the same region. A 74-year-old woman died and several others were wounded in the town. © 2022 AFP

entry.title: 3 events that shaped Xi Jinping’s worldview
entry.summary:
Xi Jinping delivers a speech at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, in 2012. | Feng Li/Getty Images
What Xi learned from the Soviet Union, the US, and the Arab Spring. When Xi Jinping was elected general secretary of the Chinese Community Party in 2012, one of the first things he did was take his senior colleagues to the National Museum in Tiananmen Square. The seven new top leaders of China walked through the “Road to Revival” exhibition, a fairly straightforward nationalist history of the country, from the first Opium War in 1840 through the present. There, Xi delivered a speech about the Chinese dream in which he set forward the goal of “achieving the great revival of the Chinese nation.” As Xi is poised to take on a third term as China’s president this week at t…

entry.title: UK's new finance minister Hunt acknowledges 'mistakes', warns of tax hikes
entry.summary: Britain's new finance minister warned Saturday of tax hikes to come as he admitted to "mistakes" made by his short-lived predecessor in a disastrous budget. Jeremy Hunt was making his first comments to media following his appointment as chancellor of the exchequer by Prime Minister Liz Truss, whose own future is in doubt mere weeks after she took office. "We will have some very difficult decisions ahead," Hunt told Sky News, warning that "all government departments" face spending restraint. "And some taxes will not be cut as quickly as people want. Some taxes will go up," he added. Tax cuts were the centrepiece of the budget announced by Hunt's predecessor Kwasi Kwarteng on September 23. But they were financed through billions in more borrowing, causing panic on financial markets which has fed into higher costs for British households. Truss fired Kwarteng on Friday and rowed back further on the planned tax cuts, but is facing threats of being toppled by senior Conservative MPs aghast at the party's collapse in opinion polls since she replaced Boris Johnson on September 6. "There were mistakes," acknowledged Hunt, a former health and foreign secretary who is seen as a centrist Tory brought in by Truss to steady her listing ship. Kwarteng and Truss had initially wanted to cut taxes for the highest earners, and had presented their budget without independent forecasts from the Office for Budget Responsibility, Hunt noted in summarizing two key mistakes. "The prime minister's recognized that, that's why I'm here." (AFP)

entry.summary: Leaks from a shadowy group of hackers targeting secret files held by the armed forces of several Latin American nations have fueled controversy in Mexico about the military's growing power. A trove of sensitive information was stolen from the Mexican defense ministry by the collective called Guacamaya, which has also claimed cyberattacks in Chile, Colombia and Peru. "Their objectives are more political than economic," said Diego Macor, a cyber-security expert at US technology giant IBM in Chile, who describes members of the network as "hacker-activists." People embrace outside a partially destroyed office building in the aftermath of Russia’s shelling of Kyiv on October 10. | Sergei Supinsky/AFP via Getty Images
Russia’s barbaric missile attack on civilians was doomed to backfire. Here’s why Putin did it anyway. Less than 48 hours after the Kerch Bridge connecting Crimea with Russia proper was damaged by a powerful blast, Vladimir Putin retaliated against Ukraine. Russia fired close to a hundred missiles at a variety of Ukrainian cities this past Monday and Tuesday. The rockets hit an array of buildings, including residences and schools, killing at least 19 civilians and injuring more than 100. entry.title: Pound slides amid UK political drama
entry.summary: The pound fell on Friday after under-fire British Prime Minister Liz Truss sacked her finance minister and made a dramatic policy U-turn, while an equity rally ran out of steam. The yen struck a new three-decade dollar low as a rise in US inflation expectations cemented expectations of more hefty Federal Reserve rate hikes. Truss sacked finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng as pressure mounted on her government following last month's big-spending, tax-slashing mini-budget, which spooked markets. The September 23 budget sent the pound tumbling to a record dollar low, near parity with the greenback, and bond yields surged before stabilizing thanks to interventions by the Bank of England. Sterling sank more than one percent to under $1.12 after Truss dismissed Kwarteng. It fell even lower after T…

entry.title: Rob Gronkowski's former Tampa Party Pad penthouse is asking for $5.4 million
entry.summary:
A penthouse in Florida Rob Gronkowski praised during his time with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, he netted $5.4 million, The Post has learned. The former NFL party block sets a record as the building’s all-time most expensive listing, known as the Towers of Channelside in Tampa. Comprised of four bedrooms and 4.5 bathrooms, the luxury residence boasts 180-degree views of the bay and the Tampa skyline — stretching all the way to downtown St. Pete, according to the listing. Built in 2011, this is the first time this unit has come to market since it was built. Features include a private lobby and elevator entrance, plus your own private pool cabana. The unit features 10-foot floor-to-ceiling windows, a gourmet kitchen, and a 1,100-square-foot wraparound deck. The property includes a 24-hour concierge, clubhouse, and resort-style pool with heated spa and rock waterfall. The unit is in the luxurious Towers of Channelside building. Photograph by Blake YeagerThe penthouse offers 180 degree views of Ybor, the downtown skyline, Harbor Island and Water Street.Photograph by Blake YeagerThe wraparound terrace spans 1,000 square feet. Photograph by Blake YeagerThe gourmet kitchen. Photograph by Blake YeagerThe penthouse has 12 foot high ceilings. BLAKE YEAGER “An opulent oasis, each element has been designed to enhance its breathtaking views and provide functionality for every lifestyle.” Listing agent Nick Janovsky, of Premier Sotheby’s International Realty, told the Post. “It also presents a rare opportunity to own a penthouse in Tampa’s original luxury skyscraper.” In the three years Gronk lived in the luxury unit, the team won the Super Bowl and qualified for the playoffs. Meanwhile, he still owns a five-bedroom, six-bathroom unit in Miami that spans over 3,770 square feet. He bought the 39th floor residence in 2019 for $1.7 million. Considered one of the greatest tight ends of all time, Gronk, 33, announced his retirement for the second time on June 21, 2022.
Source Link

entry.title: Death toll in coal mine explosion in Turkey rises to 28
entry.summary: BARTIN, Turkey (Reuters) - An explosion in a coal mine in Turkey's northern Bartin province on Friday killed 28 people, Health Minister Fahrettin Koca said, as rescue teams continued to search for people trapped underground. Eleven of the 58 rescued miners were still getting treatment in hospitals, Koca also said on Twitter, but it was not clear how many people were still trapped due to the blast that occurred as 110 people were working. Authorities said initial indications were that the blast was caused by firedamp, a term referring to methane in coal mines. Colleagues and families of the miners were waiting at the sidelines of the scene and at hospitals where the wounded are being treated, Reuters and local media footage showed. In 2014, 301 workers were killed in Turkey 's worst ever mining disaster in the western town of Soma, 350 kms (217 miles) south of Istanbul. (Reporting by Mert Ozkan,; Writing by Ezgi Erkoyun; Editing by Emelia Sithole-Matarise)

entry.summary:
Following a $117 million exploit on October 11, the Mango Markets community is close to reaching a deal with its hacker, allowing the hacker to keep $47 million in bug bounty, according to the decentralized finance (DeFI) protocol governance forum. The proposed terms reveal that $67 million of the stolen tokens will be returned, while $47 million will be retained by the hacker. 98% of voters, or 291 million tokens, voted in favor of the deal, which also stipulates that Mango Markets will not pursue criminal charges in the matter. The quorum being reached, the vote should take place on October 15th. The proposal stated:

entry.title: Trump releases 14-page response to January 6 committee
entry.summary: Former president donald trump officially responded to the Select of January 6 Committee with a superb 14-page reprimand which served as something of a compendium of his baseless allegations of voter fraud and his breathless declaration of the “crime of the century” – without addressing any of the merits of the damning evidence provided in multiple hearings. Curiously absent from this relatively voluminous memo? Any indication as to whether or not he will agree to testify before the committee. Trump’s missive takes the approach that the best defense is a good offense, though it’s debatable whether that particular playbook still works. To put Trump’s situation into context, even the hardcore conservative editorial board of the the wall street journal rented the committee’s accomplishments …

entry.title: Herschel Walker and Raphael Warnock clash over abortion and economics in highly anticipated Senate debate
entry.summary:
savanna — Senate candidates Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker faced off Friday night in their first and only scheduled pre-election debate, covering a wide range of topics crucial to the state’s voters. Both candidates pledged in their opening remarks to be strong supporters of Georgia in Washington. Warnock said he grew up in public housing on the same street as the debate, telling viewers that “only in the United States is my story possible.” The candidates discussed many critical issues for the state, including the economy, electoral integrity and abortion. Throughout the debate, Walker repeatedly tried to link Warnock to President Biden, telling voters that Warnock voted 96% of the time for the president.
Warnock declined to say whether he would support Biden if he ran…

entry.title: Herschel Walker blames high insulin prices on diabetics
entry.summary:
Herschel Walker wasn’t completely gaffe during the 15-minute debate as he blamed diabetics for the high price of insulin. video:
Walker: You don’t need insulin if you don’t eat well, so food prices are more important (??????) #GASen Debate pic.twitter.com/LesqASABk7 — Pat Dennis (@patdennis) October 14, 2022
Walker said: “I believe in reducing insulin, but at the same time, you have to eat well because he may not know and I know a lot of people who are using insulin and unless you are eating well, insulin is not good for you. So you have to reduce food price.” This is not how insulin works. People with diabetes cannot make their diabetes go away just by eating right. Herschel Walker is a disaster in this debate. He’s not a good debater, but Walker has the standard Fox News talking points on these issues. Herschel Walker thinks he won the debate by interrupting and yelling. Walker’s actions came straight out of Donald Trump’s playbook in 2016. Herschel Walker may be the country’s most extreme Senate candidate this year, and blaming insulin prices on diabetics is a new low.
Source: Politicususa.com

entry.title: The January 6 hearings make Trump look guilty. But, is it important?
entry.summary:
Amid the alleged finale of the January 6 hearings on Thursday, a spoiler arrived in the form of a reports that committee members voted to subpoena former President Donald Trump to testify under oath.
The building of this now lost conclusion began with Bennie Thompson, chairman of the House Select Committee investigating the January 6, 2021 attack on the US Capitol, trying to convince persistent skeptics of their work. Thompson assured critics on Thursday that the committee’s findings were not part of a broad liberal conspiracy portrayed in conservative media.
“When you look back at what came out of the work of this committee, the most striking fact is that all of this evidence comes almost entirely from Republicans,” Thompson said. Explain.
Republicans like Steve Bannon, to whom …

entry.title: Australia floods: why the country is battling weather again
entry.summary: (Reuters) - Floods caused by torrential rain are hitting large swathes of southeast Australia, inundating hundreds of homes and forcing authorities to urge thousands of people to evacuate. Areas of three southeastern states - Victoria, New South Wales and the island state of Tasmania - are under emergency flood warnings after an intense weather system this week brought more than a month's worth of rain to the southeast. The crisis comes after flooding in March and April on the east coast resulted in A$4.8 billion ($3.3 billion) in insured damage, according to the Insurance Council of Australia. WHERE IS THE FLOODING? Victoria has been the state hardest hit by the current floods, with several rivers in the state at major flood levels. The Goulburn River at Seymour, about 100 km (60 miles) n…

entry.title: Erdogan Backs Putin Gas Pipeline Hub Proposal
entry.summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin, right, and Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan shake hands during their meeting on sidelines of the Conference on Interaction and Confidence Building Measures in Asia (CICA) summit, in Astana, Kazakhstan, Thursday, Oct. 13, 2022. (Vyacheslav Prokofyev, Sputnik, Kremlin Pool Photo via AP) Reuters: Turkey backs Putin gas plan as Nord Stream faces long outage LONDON (Reuters) - Large sections of the damaged Nord Stream pipelines built to supply gas to Europe might need to be replaced, the head of Gazprom said, while Turkey on Friday backed Russian proposals to build a gas hub there as an alternative supply route. Russian President Vladimir Putin this week proposed Turkey as a base for gas supplies after the Nord Stream pipelines under the Baltic Sea were damaged last month by blasts. The European Union, which previously turned to Russia for about 40% of its gas needs, is however seeking to wean itself off Russian energy following the invasion of Ukraine in February. Read more .... Update #1: Erdogan says Turkey and Russia to study Putin’s gas hub proposal (Al Jazeera) Update #2: Erdogan Eager To Act On Putin's Offer To Make Turkey A 'Gas Hub' (Zero Hedge) WNU Editor: Not surprising that Erdogan is all in on it. It would mean billions in revenue to Turkey, and leverage over Europe should the EU find itself in an energy crunch.

entry.title: Rupert Murdoch considers combining Fox, News Corp
entry.summary: By Yuvraj Malik and Dawn Chmielewski (Reuters) -Rupert Murdoch has started a process that could reunite his media empire, News Corp and Fox Corp disclosed on Friday, saying they would consider combining at his behest, nearly a decade after the companies split. Both have formed special committees to review proposals of a potential combination, they said. If a deal goes through, the combination will allow Murdoch greater control over his media assets and help the companies trim costs. Media companies are fighting decades-low growth in advertising sales and for users' attention against deep-pocketed social media and content websites. After years of expansion globally, Murdoch split his empire in 2013, placing the print business in newly created public entity News Corp and the TV and entertain…

entry.title: Poll Finds Westerners In No Mood For Concessions To Russia In Ukraine
entry.summary: The Guardian: Westerners in no mood for concessions to Russia in Ukraine, poll finds Exclusive: Survey shows strong support within alliance for tougher sanctions and Nato aid, but more pro-Russia views elsewhere Nearly eight months into Vladimir Putin’s war on Ukraine, citizens in core western alliance countries show little appetite for the kind of concessions to Russia that might form part of an eventual agreement to end the fighting, according to a major survey. The YouGov-Cambridge globalism project, which gauged public opinion in 25 of the world’s largest countries, also found strong support for maintaining, and often toughening and expanding, military and economic measures against Moscow. Read more .... WNU Editor: It looks like positions are hardening.

entry.title: Western Governments Are Making Plans To Avoid Public Panic If A Nuclear Incident Occurs In Ukraine
entry.summary: The Guardian: West makes plans to avoid panic if Russia uses nuclear bomb in Ukraine Crisis is considered unlikely but officials re-examine plans to provide support for fearful populations Western officials are engaged in “prudent planning” behind the scenes to prevent chaos and panic in their home countries in the event Russia was to detonate a nuclear bomb in or near Ukraine. Although a nuclear crisis is considered highly unlikely, the insider said officials internationally were re-examining plans to provide emergency support and reassurance to populations fearful of nuclear escalation. Hints of the thinking emerged in a briefing by an official on Friday, who was asked if there would be measures in place to prevent panic buying or people fleeing cities en masse in fear of escalation after a nuclear event. Read more .... WNU Editor: You can take this to the bank. If there is a nuclear incident in Ukraine, there will be global mass panic. The stores will be empty within 24 hours.

entry.summary: A pair of climate activists tossed a couple of cans of tomato soup on one of Vincent van Gogh's famous glass-protected paintings at a London museum on Friday, renewing a debate about the effectiveness of some of their group's strategies. Phoebe Plummer, 21, and Anna Holland, 20—who glued their hands to the National Gallery wall after dousing the $84.2 million "Sunflowers" in soup—wore Just Stop Oil (JSO) T-shirts. The U.K.-based group shared footage of the action and their motivations on social media. "Is art worth more than life? More than food? More than justice?" Plummer said in a statement. "The cost-of-living crisis is driven by fossil fuels—everyday life has become unaffordable for millions of cold, hungry families—they can't even afford to heat a tin of soup." In the past eight years she has sold only two crates (100 kilogrammes) of the fruit because of poor harvests. She turned her attention to vegetables instead but the production was low because of a water shortage.

entry.title: Ukraine completes exhumation of soldiers at Lyman mass grave
entry.summary: (Reuters) - Ukrainian investigators have completed the exhumation of soldiers in one of two mass graves discovered after Russian troops retreated from the town of Lyman in eastern Donetsk region, police said on Friday. "Police have removed the bodies of 34 Ukrainian defenders from the mass grave," Donetsk regional police said in a statement. "Work continues at a second location where more than 120 civilians are buried. The fate of each person who died will be determined." The soldiers' bodies have all been transferred to a morgue and will be returned to their relatives for burial once identification has taken place and the cause of death is determined, the police said. Since Sept. 29, Donetsk police said they had found the bodies of 144 people, 85 of them civilians, with 108 exhumed from makeshift graves, and the rest found in buildings or on the streets. "Most of the dead -- 85 -- are civilians," they said. "Some of them have signs of violent death, in particular shrapnel injuries. Ukraine's top prosecutor told a joint news conference with International Criminal Court prosecutor Karim Khan in The Hague on Thursday that Ukraine had 28 investigative teams on the ground in areas recently recaptured by Ukrainian forces. Prosecutor General Andriy Kostin said retreating Russian troops had left evidence of illegal detention and torture of civilians and deportations. Khan, who opened an ICC investigation in March, would not be drawn on when his office might file its first case, saying he would move forward "when the evidence is sufficient". In Lyman, graves marked as holding the bodies of people killed in May, when Russians were battling to seize Lyman, include those for children as young as one, Reuters reported this week. Reuters could not independently determine the causes or timing of the deaths. Ukrainian authorities have repeatedly accused Russian troops of committing atrocities in occupied territories, a charge Moscow denies. (Reporting by Elaine Monaghan; Editing by David Gregorio)

entry.title: Zelenskiy promises victory as Ukraine marks Defenders Day
entry.summary: KYIV (Reuters) - President Volodymyr Zelenskiy marked Ukraine's Defenders Day holiday on Friday by promising victory over Russia and freedom for Ukraine. In a video address delivered on hills outside the capital Kyiv, Zelenskiy thanked Ukraine's armed forces for defending their country. He said everything that had been taken away from Ukraine would be returned, and no soldier left in captivity. "It seems that the current enemy in its evil unites all the enemies of our statehood that we faced before," Zelenskiy said on the wooded hills outside the village of Vitachyv, site of an historic military outpost overlooking the Dnipro River. "By defeating this enemy, we will respond to all enemies who encroached on Ukraine - on those who lived, who live and who will live on our land. This will be a victory for all our people. This will be a victory for the Armed Forces of Ukraine." Russia's invasion of Ukraine, launched on Feb. 24, has killed thousands, displaced millions, pulverised cities and damaged the global economy. Ukrainian forces have made advances in recent weeks, but Russia has carried out heavy air strikes that hit energy facilities as well as apartment blocks this week. "The world sees that Ukrainians do not lose their humanity under any circumstances. The enemy can strike at our cities, but never at our dignity," Zelenskiy, who was dressed in khaki, said in his video address marking the Oct. 14 public holiday. (Writing in Melbourne by Lidia Kelly, Editing by Timothy Heritage)

entry.title: Trump writes letter to the Jan 6 committee after its vote to subpoena him and brags about the size of the crowd
entry.summary: A day after the House select committee on January 6 unanimously voted to subpoena former President Trump, he responded with an angry letter to committee chairman Bennie Thompson to complain about his work. The select committee is investigating the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021 and its causes, with the aim of determining who was responsible for the chaos and preventing it from happening again. Trump did not mention the subpoena and instead criticized the committee; he said he was writing “to express our anger, disappointment and grievance at all the hundreds of millions of dollars spent on what many consider a hoax and witch hunt”. He also attacked the committee for failing to investigate voter fraud and appeared to defend the committee’s targets, who he said were merely acting “as con…

entry.title: Trump crushed as judge makes executive privilege claim and forces Pence aide to testify before Justice Department criminal grand jury
entry.summary:
A federal judge has rejected Trump’s claims of executive privilege and forced a top Mike Pence aide to testify before a 1/6 criminal grand jury. The Washington Post reported: U.S. Chief District Judge Beryl A. Howell has ruled in a sealed decision that could clear the way for other top Trump White House officials to answer questions before a grand jury that Pence’s former chief of staff Mark Short may have had the Information important to criminals The investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the Capitol was not available from other sources, one of the people said. Trump appealed, but the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit declined to delay Short’s appearance while the lawsuit continued, a sign that Trump’s attempts to invoke executive privilege to protect the confidentiality of the president’s decisions are not likely to be accounted for, people familiar with the matter said. upper hand. The ruling has very important implications because it means that senior Trump White House officials and aides, including Trump himself, could be forced to investigate the 1/6 attack and Trump and his administration’s criminal grand jury before a Justice Department criminal grand jury. Testify on potential effects. about what Trump did and Didn’t do it when the Capitol was attacked Rise to the criminal level. Now, those in the White House on 1/6 are forced to testify in a criminal investigation that could have real consequences for Trump.
Source: Politicususa.com

entry.title: The media covers the irresponsible vandalism of Van Gogh's sunflowers
entry.summary: Two environmental protesters put on a show by throwing soup at a priceless piece of art and sticking to the wall of the museum, and several outlets sent the wrong message by rewarding their ecoterrorism. Protesters, who identified themselves as part of a group called ‘Just Stop Oil’, threw two cans of Heinz Tomato Soup at by Vincent Van Gogh “Sunflowers” then stuck their hands to the wall at the National Gallery in London on Friday. The painting is from the second series of sunflower still lifes that the Dutch artist created in 1888 with the cheerful yellow flowers. It is among his most famous and beloved works and has a estimated value of $84.2 million. Monetary calculations aside, the value of such a historic piece of art is truly priceless, and fortunately the painting was behind p…

entry.title: Alex Jones doesn't go away so easily
entry.summary:
In this country, there are so many ways to deal with a man like Alex Jones.
On Wednesday, a Connecticut jury did its best to force the Infowars host and owner to face the consequences of the harm his lies caused others, ordering Jones to pay $965 million to relatives of the victims of a mass shooting in 2012 and to an FBI agent whom he accused of being all actors.
In a interview with “PBS NewsHour”, litigator Jesse Gessin describe the nearly billion-dollar judgment as “probably one of the largest libel verdicts in United States history.”
The largest sum, $120 million, went to Robbie Parker, whose 6-year-old daughter, Emilie, was killed in the attack on Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown. Outside the courtroom, parker said he was proud that “what we were able to accomplish …

entry.title: Roger Stone blows a gasket and says Jared Kushner has an IQ of 70 and Ivanka Trump is an abortionist B*tch
entry.summary:
Newly released documentary footage appears to show Roger Stone losing it and calling Ivanka Trump an abortion because her father refused to pardon him again. Stone video:
Unreleased subpoena footage: Stone, angry at Trump for not granting him a second pardon, calls Ivanka Trump the daughter of an abortion bitch. pic.twitter.com/aAAOZLC5fu — Christopher Gould Branson (@cguld) October 14, 2022
Stone said in the clip: “Jared Kushner has an IQ of 70. He’s going to come to Miami. We’re going to kick him out of Miami very quickly. He’s going to leave soon, very soon. He’s got a hundred guards. I’m going to have 5,000 security guards. Do you want to fight? Let’s fight. Fuck you. Fuck you, and your aborted bitch daughter.” The Jan. 6 attacks, Trump’s coup plot, and narcissism fueled the perpetrators’ decision-making process, and a documentary film crew followed them, giving us an insight into how Trump and those around him operate. Roger Stone was upset that Donald Trump refused to grant him a second pardon, ostensibly to cover up his activities in the 1/6 attack. Here’s the Stone video from the documentary filmmaker who posted the above footage, released by the committee on Thursday, Jan. 6:
Recently, the select committee obtained footage of Roger Stone before and after the election. pic.twitter.com/6mRdWwMSmE — January 6 Committee (@January6thCmte) October 13, 2022
Even before yesterday’s hearing, Zachary Petrizzo was the daily beast Stone ‘threatened to file a $25 million lawsuit against Danish filmmakers – Frederick Mabel and Christopher Gould Branson – who took his picture in November, saying’ Fuck the vote and let’s face violence.'” Stone may return to the prison where he belongs. Trump’s longtime adviser is a go-between for the Trump campaign and Russia, and has performed the same functions for Trump on 1/6 with the militia. The failed former president was surrounded by criminal associates like Roger Stone who were only interested in himself.
Source: Politicususa.com

entry.title: Judge Keeps DACA Immigration Program Alive for Current Recipients - For Now
entry.summary: A federal judge in Texas said Friday that, for now, it would allow about 600,000 immigrants “Dreamers“enrolled in Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) to continue renewing its two-year protections against deportation and work permits as the legal process over Obama-era politics continues. At the same time, U.S. District Court Judge Andrew Hanen said he would continue to bar the federal government from approving new DACA applications, a block he first issued in July 2021when he agreed with arguments put forward by Republican-led states and declared the program illegal. Friday’s order was in response to a ruling earlier this month by the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, which also found that the Obama administration lacked the legal authority to create DACA in 2012. The appeals cour…

entry.title: 'This time feels different': Iran’s women and youth-led protests continue to grow amid brutal crackdown
entry.summary: Anti-government protests in Iran, first sparked last month by the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini, have moved into their fourth week. The youth and women-led protests cross class and ethnic divides, and the demands have grown in scale and scope, with many, even in the clerical community, now calling for the complete abolition of the Islamic Republic. Many sectors of society, including businesses and unions, have also joined in protest, with oil workers from one of the country’s major refineries going on strike Monday. Iranian authorities have launched a violent assault on protesters in response, explains Amnesty International’s Raha Bahreini, with security forces shooting live ammunition into crowds to disperse the protests, leaving thousands injured and at least 144 victims dead, 24 of t…

entry.title: Putin Says He Sees No Need For Talks With Biden Right Now
entry.summary: TASS: Putin sees no need for talks with Biden for now The Russian president stressed that at the moment no direct talks with any of the leaders of the other states participating in the G20 summit were on the agenda ASTANA, October 14. /TASS/. Russian President Vladimir Putin has said that he sees no need at the moment for talks with US President Joe Biden. "He should be asked whether he is ready to hold such negotiations with me or not. To be honest, I don’t see any need by and large. There is no platform for any negotiations for the time being," Putin told the media on Friday, when asked about the possibility of a meeting with Biden at the G20 summit in Indonesia. Read more .... entry.title: Russian President Putin Says He Has No Regrets When Asked About Ukraine
entry.summary: TASS: Asked about Ukraine, Putin said he had no regrets "I want to make it clear: what is happening today is unpleasant, to put it mildly. But we would have had the same thing a little bit later, only in different conditions, far worse for us," the Russian leader stressed ASTANA, October 14. /TASS/. Russia is acting correctly and in a timely manner in the current situation involving Ukraine, Russian President Vladimir Putin told the media on Friday. "No," Putin replied when asked, if he had any regrets. Read more .... Update: Putin Says He Has No Regrets About Ukraine Invasion After Reverses (Bloomberg) WNU Editor: His body language when asked that question was very clear. With his shrug, especially when he said that he does not want to destroy Ukraine, tells me that as far as he is concerned he had no choice. Here is an easy prediction. Years and decades from now historians are going to be debating if Putin did have a choice, and how different everything would have been if a different choice was available and taken.

entry.title: Musk says cannot fund Starlink in Ukraine indefinitely
entry.summary: Elon Musk said Friday his company SpaceX wouldn't be able to fund the Starlink satellite internet network over Ukraine indefinitely, amid reports he had asked the US military to cover the costs. The move comes as Musk has been embroiled in public spats with Ukranian leaders who were angered by his controversial proposals for de-escalating the conflict, which included acknowledging Russian sovereignty over Crimea. Starlink, a constellation of over 3,000 small satellites in low Earth orbit, has been vital to Ukraine's war effort against Russia, with SpaceX donating some 25,000 ground terminals, according to an updated figure given by Musk last week. In a series of tweets, the world's richest man appeared to confirm a report by CNN saying he had written to the Pentagon warning that his financ…

entry.title: Khamenei warns Islamic Republic is a 'mighty tree' that cannot be uprooted
entry.summary: By Parisa Hafezi DUBAI (Reuters) -Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said on Friday that no one should dare think they can uproot the Islamic Republic, in his toughest warning to protesters since Mahsa Amini's death in police custody ignited nationwide unrest now in its fourth week. Demonstrations by people from all walks of life, after the Iranian Kurdish woman's death following her arrest for "inappropriate attire", have evolved into widespread calls for the downfall of Khamenei and "Death to the Islamic Republic". The protests mark one of the boldest challenges to clerical rule since the 1979 revolution, even if the unrest does not seem close to toppling the system. Khamenei compared the Islamic Republic to an unshakeable tree. "That seedling is a mighty tree now and no one sh…

entry.title: Defiant Putin says Russia 'doing everything right' in Ukraine
entry.summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Friday that Moscow was conducting its nearly eight-month invasion of Ukraine correctly, despite his forces' early failure to topple Kyiv and a string of recent embarrassing battlefield defeats. But his comments came hours after Kremlin-installed officials in Ukraine's southern region of Kherson urged residents to leave, pointing to nearing Ukrainian artillery and as Kyiv announced its forces were pushing closer towards the region's main city. And on Thursday Moscow also hinted at the potentially wide extent of the damage dealt to the Crimea bridge, saying it could take many months to complete repairs after a recent blast rocked the key supply link between Russia and the annexed Crimean peninsula. "What is happening today is not pleasant. But all the…

entry.title: Russian President Putin Foresees An End To Mobilization In Two Weeks
entry.summary: Politico: Putin claims ‘partial mobilization’ to end in 2 weeks, with 222,000 reservists called up so far ‘Nothing further is being planned’ after draft of 300,000 is complete, Russian president claims. Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday claimed his country’s so-called partial mobilization of reservists to fight in the Ukraine war, announced last month, will end in around two weeks. “This work is already coming to an end,” Putin said at a press conference in Astana, where he traveled to participate in a conference. “There are now 222,000 people mobilized in the troop formations, out of 300,000. I think that within about two weeks all mobilization activities will be completed.” Putin also said that “nothing further is being planned … within the foreseeable future,” as his defense ministry had not requested further troops. Read more .... WNU Editor: The press gangs are in operation .... Russia's conscript catchers snatch men off the streets to be sent as fresh 'cannon fodder' for Putin's war in Ukraine (Daily Mail). Russian President Putin Foresees An End To Mobilization In Two Weeks Partial mobilization to end in about two weeks — Putin -- TASS Putin: Call-up of Russian reservists to finish in 2 weeks -- AP Putin claims that 16,000 enlisted Russians already fight against Ukraine -- Ukrainska Pravda Putin Says 16,000 New Recruits Have Deployed: Russia-Ukraine War News -- New York Times Putin says Ukraine mobilisation should be finished in two weeks -- Reuters Putin says mobilised troops will be ready in two weeks as he warns Nato against ‘global catastrophe’ – as it happened -- The Guardian
